meta.title: The Coaching Habit: Say Less, Ask More & Change the Way You Lead Forever
meta.author: Michael Bungay Stanier

parts.title: Importance and Underutilization of Coaching
parts.body: In a fast-paced world, leaders need coaching skills, crucial for enhancing performance and workplace culture. Yet, research shows many managers find coaching time-consuming and fail to implement it effectively. Despite many having some coaching training, only 23% felt it significantly improved their performance. Coaching remains underutilized because managers see it as slow work amidst hectic schedules.

parts.title: Coaching Benefits and Habit Building
parts.body: The Essence of Coaching Coaching can help you work less hard while having more impact by breaking the cycles of overdependence, being overwhelmed, and disconnection. These cycles keep you and your team stuck, and coaching can empower people, enabling them to work more independently. Enabling your team to be more self-sufficient not only increases their autonomy and responsibility but also ensures you spend less time solving their problems. The Simple Coaching Approach Box of Crayons emphasizes simple coaching methods that require ten minutes or less. This involves asking the right questions daily instead of just sharing advice. The Seven Essential Questions focus conversations, reduce the need to offer excessive guidance, and help maintain team momentum. Shifting the workplace culture with these fundamental questions can transform how you engage in daily interactions, achieving greater autonomy and effectiveness with your team. Building Better Habits Changing behavior is hard due to habitual actions largely influenced by the subconscious. Building effective habits requires identifying triggers, defining new behaviors that take less than a minute, and practicing them deeply. The book offers the New Habit Formula as a guide to creating specific action steps, like asking instead of telling, to encourage curiosity and diminish over-reliance on management.

parts.title: Building an Effective Coaching Habit
parts.body: Coaching isn't complex, though your first try might've failed because training was too theoretical or boring. Three reasons for struggles: courses lack connection to your real work, you don't learn how to apply insights, and changing from advice-giving to questioning is hard due to ingrained habits. However, at Box of Crayons, effective coaching can happen with simple questions in under ten minutes. Building a coaching habit involves consistent, everyday small acts rather than formal sessions. Coaching helps you work less hard, break workplace vicious circles (overdependence, feeling overwhelmed, disconnect), and enhances team autonomy. In an overdependent team, everyone feels frustrated and work gets bottlenecked; coaching increases autonomy, reducing the need for constant help. If overwhelmed by tasks, coaching enables you to focus on impactful work rather than being spread thin. Moreover, coaching connects you to meaningful work, increasing engagement and motivation. Our habits drive 45% of our actions; shifting habits requires knowing triggers and implementing micro-habits. Change includes a reason, trigger, a specific micro-habit, deep practice, and a recovery plan. Making a vow dedicated to others rather than personal gain can be more motivating. Define the habit's trigger, identify the old, and establish the new behavior. The New Habit Formula simplifies this into an actionable, understandable change process. Building habits requires courage, resilience, and starting with the simplest, impactful steps.

parts.title: Shaping Habits & Asking Effective Questions
parts.body:
Shaping Habits: Insights and Strategies

Ovid wisely noted that nothing is more powerful than habit. Habits can create a life filled with undesirable responses, but understanding how they work allows you to craft successful routines. By shaping your habits intentionally, you can influence your behavior and life in positive ways. Begin by focusing on one habit at a time, and use support systems like apps or buddies to reinforce good behaviors.

Importance of Asking Questions

Asking effective questions can make conversations more meaningful. Avoid "drive-by questioning," which can overwhelm and confuse, turning a supportive talk into an interrogation. When engaging in conversations, remember to ask one question at a time to keep the focus on understanding and truly listening. Try asking "What's on your mind?" to guide discussions toward what truly matters to the person you're speaking with.

The Power of Habits and Questions

Habits are like buildings shaping us after we've shaped them. By fostering rock-solid habits, such as asking impactful questions, you foster deeper connections and address both performance and development in coaching. The 3P model helps decide the focus of coaching - either on projects, people, or patterns, and helps guide the conversation towards more meaningful development rather than just fixing immediate issues.

parts.title: Clarifying Thoughts for Better Choices
parts.body: When we have something on our mind, it can affect our choices and perspective, maybe limiting our optimal decisions. The Kickstart Question helps by releasing the pressure and clarifying what's subtly influencing our thoughts. This question assists in shifting a possibly narrow view to a broader perspective. The Kickstart Question functions like a small pressure-release valve, putting potential biases and influences out in the open. Our thoughts can narrow how we approach situations, but by identifying them we can prevent them from dominant decisions. This process can foster clarity and improve decision making. The act of naming these unformed thoughts can break free the challenge from fuzziness. Once released, it's easier to manage, leading to less restrictive thinking and more effective problem-solving. By making implicit influences explicit, we enhance our ability to make well-rounded choices.

parts.title: Unlocking Insights Through Reconsideration and Follow-Up Questions
parts.body: Studies show that allowing students to reconsider answers leads to better performance. When given a chance to think again, they often correct their mistakes, showing the importance of reflection for accuracy. Recent findings emphasize higher-level thinking questions, such as asking "What else?" to deepen understanding and encourage participation. Psychological experiment with three-year-olds demonstrated that, even when tempted to lie, children often reveal the truth when asked follow-up questions. This study suggests that, like children, adults may have more hidden insights that can be revealed through probing with the AWE Question. This highlights the importance of commitment to an answer and asking follow-up questions which are crucial to unlocking deeper truths and experiences. The AWE Question effectively helps uncover these hidden insights, promoting a more comprehensive understanding through targeted inquiry.

parts.title: Identifying Core Challenges and Understanding Wants vs. Needs
parts.body: Understanding true challenges can empower teams and individuals. Instead of quickly jumping to solutions, focus on the real challenge by asking probing questions like, "What's the real challenge here for you?" and repeating, "And what else?" Doing so surfaces the underlying challenges that often go unnoticed when immediate solutions are sought. This is crucial when everyone immediately starts offering solutions in discussions and overlooking the defining problem. Typical old habits include quickly assuming the first identified challenge is the primary one and racing towards action without truly understanding the core issue. These tendencies lead to addressing challenges at a superficial level or conflating multiple smaller issues as equally pressing. Instead, the proposed new habit emphasizes regular use of the Focus Question to help isolate the most significant challenges by repeatedly asking and delving into what else might be a concern. The content also introduces The Foundation Question: "What do you want?" This question, combined with understanding underlying needs, helps in identifying authentic requests and desires. Often, people misinterpret wants for needs, obscuring genuine desires and outcomes they seek. The discussion emphasizes the need for clarity and honesty in communication to bridge gaps in understanding and decision-making, both within oneself and in interactions with others.

parts.title: Understanding Brain Responses to Safety and Risk
parts.body: Your brain evaluates safety in new environments, impacting your thinking and engagement. A sense of safety fosters a mindset open to ambiguity and positive interactions, while fear triggers a fight-or-flight response. Evolution's bias towards perceiving danger means we default to caution when unsure, leading to retreat rather than engagement.

parts.title: Avoid Unnecessary Rescues: Setting Boundaries and Empowering Others
parts.body: Avoid Unnecessary Helping This section emphasizes the importance of not jumping into helping others just because they ask or because you feel obligated. Often, people may just want to vent or figure things out themselves. They suggest asking, "How can I help?" to get clarity on how you can truly be of assistance. If unsure about how your offer will be received, soften it with phrases like, "Out of curiosity" or "Just so I know…". Decision Anxiety and Options Many worry about the daunting tasks that might follow asking, "How can I help?" However, the text suggests you have a range of responses; rather than always saying "Yes," you can say "No", or "I can't do that, but I could" offer something else. This encourages setting boundaries to prevent overcommitment and stress. Encouraging Self-Solution When someone asks for advice, resist the urge to spoon-feed them answers. Instead, turn the question back to them by asking what solutions they think might work. This fosters their independence and problem-solving skills, allowing you to contribute only after they’ve explored their own options. This approach helps avoid the "rescuer" role, which can be draining.

parts.title: Promoting Effective Conversations and Learning
parts.body: Call and Response Techniques: When engaging in conversations, especially after asking insightful questions, it's essential to acknowledge the person’s answers to encourage and confirm they are heard. Acknowledging the response could be as simple as saying, "That's good," which can validate them and make them feel valued. This creates a space where learning and exchanging new ideas can flourish, enhancing the conversation's effectiveness. Double-Loop Learning: This concept involves making sure learning goes beyond just solving problems; it focuses on understanding the issue at hand to extract meaningful lessons. Questions like "What was most useful for you?" promote reflection and help in embedding learning. They are instrumental for helping individuals process and retain new information by allowing them to generate answers themselves, creating new neural pathways. Effective Learning Techniques: Strategies to improve knowledge retention include reflecting on learned concepts, which can be bolstered by asking "What have you learned since our last conversation?" This question encourages continual reflection and retrieval of information. Neuroscience suggests that recalling and reflecting on learned ideas solidifies memory and understanding, thus preventing the process of forgetting.

parts.title: Enhancing Online and Managerial Communication Skills
parts.body:
Changing Communication Habits Online

We've become accustomed to handling communication via screens—emails, texts, and social media messages are a big part of our life. Changing our communication approach to be more effective involves giving less advice and more curiosity-focused questions. When you receive a long-winded email, instead of jumping in with advice, deploy one of the Seven Essential Questions to help the person think through solving their issue. This approach can save time and make your interactions more useful.

Challenges of Managing Advice

Managers often feel pressured to provide detailed advice. The book suggests that when the "Advice Monster" is triggered—especially via email—it's better to use one of the targeted questions that can guide the conversation more productively. Examples include asking, "What’s the real challenge here for you?" This reduces your workload and helps others develop their problem-solving skills. It's a habit change that makes your input more impactful and less draining.

Building a Habit of Curiosity

To make a lasting change in how you interact and assist others, the book advocates focusing on curiosity rather than advice. You should find or even create your own effective questions that align with your voice while embracing a coaching mentality in everyday interactions. This can enhance your management skills, professional growth, and personal relationships, leading to more meaningful and productive conversations. Choose curiosity to lead to less effort and greater impact.
